section.name: WhatIs
section.title: What is
section.description: what is the goal of this program?

chapter.section:
∓ is a simple program whose primary aim is to plot data, more precisely to render an interactive 2-d graphical representation of a set of arrays of numbers. It comes to facilitate a typical task of engineering: view and analyze of a set of collected values.
This program is meant to:
Plot data contained in a text file Allow user to inspect data and perform simple measurements Perform some simple postprocessing and data elaboration Export plot to text and image (ex, to include in &WYSIWYG; editors)
For the usual reason: haven't found what I wanted. I missed a simple, fast and complete tool to visualize the measures collected in a servo drive, so I decided to write from scratch a new one for me.

section.name: Features
section.title: Program Features
section.description: a brief list of program functions and capabilities

chapter.section:
Some program features are:
Installer not required: all is comprised in a single executable, don't need a setup nor particular third party stuff
Does not write anything on &windows; registry, so does not require an uninstaller
Supports command line arguments, user can choose if create a new instance or use an existing one
Graphic interface includes Select, Edit, Pan, Zoom, Measure and Pen tools
Plots can be organized in more &frame;s, allowing data comparison
Frames can have different scales Frames layout is adjustable with drag and drop Frames visualization can be synchronized (, )
Plots can be exported to:
Text format &matlab; m-file Bitmap formats (&gif;, &bmp;) Vectorial image (&emf;, &svg;)
Supported compression formats (see here here for more info and required &DLL;s):
zip archives (*.zip) &sqx; archives (*.sqx) gzipped files (*.gz)
Flexible text data parser
can handle columns having different size can perform some data processing like rescale/offset, split, reorder/resample
Ehmm, see todo list
Some program limitations are:
Only 2-d graphs
Values are internally represented by &IEEE; 754 double precision (64bit,15-digit precision) floating point numbers, whose range is about 2.23E-308<|X|<1.79E308; exceeding this range causes math errors
Indexes are represented by 32bit signed integers, so data files larger than 2Gb are not supported
Does not support Unicode (using char)
As any program, ∓ interacts with your system; here's a list of what could happen when you run it.
Clipboard overwrite, typically when requesting Media write requests, as specified in the next section
By developer choice, ∓ does not write anything in &windows; registry, so handy things like shell integration or file type association are up to users. The program may request to write temporary data in the temporary directory set in option (the default should be in the system temporary directory %TEMP%\~MattPlot\); generally the deletion of these files is up to system maintainance. Informations that must last over one execution time are stored in MattPlot.ini file, placed in program directory.
Summarizing, the reasons that lead ∓ to request write access to storage media are:
On request to edit or store options On request of help file, creation of MattPlot.chm, if missing, in the temporary directory On opening compressed data, to decompress them in temporary directory On crash, creation of a *.log files in the working directory On action On file save user request On starting and on closing, ∓ may try to delete some temporary files

section.subsection:
During program execution plotted data are permanently buffered in &RAM;; this imply a dependency of memory occupation on the amount of handled data.
To describe how much memory is consumed by data, consider this typical use:
a text file containing ten thousands pairs of numbers; assuming string literals of 34 characters per number, in the worst case of file complete buffering, are needed about 700 Kbyte of &RAM; (once parser had done its work, this memory can be freed).
Next we need to store numbers: using 64 bit floating point type we need about 160 Kbyte for the data binary representation, which may increase to 240 Kbyte if stored as complex.
Finally, when performing calculations, data container may be temporarily copied doubling the actual used &RAM;.
Now let's talk about the memory needed by the program itself. The actual code is probably a negligible part respect linked libraries (&VCL; classes, standard library, etc...); total code will easily reach few Mbyte. Moreover, for performance reasons, the graphic interface is buffered: for example, considering a 800x600 form, we require 800x600x3 byte ~= 1.4 Mbyte of space for the bitmap buffer used to avoid flicker during the repaint.
The conclusion is that the data size become comparable with program size when we deal with at least 100000÷200000 points (pairs of double).

chapter.section:
A brief description of program related files.
File nameDescriptionNote
MattPlot.exe &windows; 32 bit executable The program itself (no other files neeeded)
DefaultDir The working directory Set in option entry
TempDir The temporary directory (\~MattPlot\) Set in option entry
MattPlot.chm µsoft; compiled &HTML; help Generated in TempDir at request. Requires a HtmlHelp viewer (hh.exe, generally present in all &windows; systems)
MattPlot.ini Program options file Fixed name and position (same exe directory); initially not present, create with
*.mpl ∓`s text data file Plot data in text format; this is a fake extension that provide the possibility to filter files and associate ∓ with them
*.mpx ∓`s &XML; plot description format Plot complete description in &XML; format
*.log ∓`s crash log files A text file containing the program log lines, autosaved in case of critical errors
The ∓ win32 binary distribution consists in a single executable file named MattPlot.exe. All related files and documentation is contained in that file.
